title: Gasoline Pump Calculus
driving_question: How can we use calculus to model real-world situations such as the flow of gasoline into a tank?
short_background_context: In this mission, we will be exploring a real-world scenario involving a customer at a gas station pumping gasoline into a gas tank. The rate of flow of gasoline is modeled by a differentiable function, f, where f(t) is measured in gallons per second and t is measured in seconds since pumping began. We will be using concepts from algebra, statistics, and economics to understand and solve problems related to this scenario.
tasks: Interpret the meaning of the integral from 60 to 135 seconds of f(t) in the context of the problem. Use a right Riemann sum with the three subintervals [60, 90], [90, 120], and [120, 135] to approximate the value of the integral.
Determine if there must exist a value of c, for 60 < c < 120, such that f'(c) = 0. Justify your answer.
Calculate the total number of gallons of gasoline pumped into the gas tank from time t = 60 seconds to time t = 135 seconds.
pre_thinking_prompts: What does the function f(t) represent in this scenario?
What are the subintervals [60, 90], [90, 120], and [120, 135] used for?
What does it mean for a function to be differentiable?
reflection_prompt: What did you learn about using calculus to model real-world scenarios? How can these concepts be applied to other real-world situations?
ai_tutor_prompts: Can you explain why you chose those particular subintervals for the Riemann sum?
Why is it important to know if there exists a value of c such that f'(c) = 0?
How did you calculate the total number of gallons of gasoline pumped into the gas tank?
remix_zone: Consider a different scenario where the rate of flow of gasoline changes over time in a different way. How would you adjust the tasks to fit this new scenario?
